Posts.Content: Hi Winky I've just finished radiotherapy which I started 10 weeks after mastectomy & reconstruction with expander implant, as had to wait a few extra weeks for the wound to heal completely so that the implant could be expanded, the BCN said that a slight delay is ok but should start within 12 weeks of surgery.  Best wishes
Posts.Title: May not have Radiotherapy (Getting very frustrated)

Posts.Content: Hi Caz90 My Onco score was 16 and I wasn't 'offered' chemo as was told would only be 1% benefit.  During discussions my oncologist said that a score between 20-23 was an area of much debate between oncologists as to the benefit/risk ratio, I would say that your oncologist is the one to best advise you rather than the BCN, no offence to them. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Intermediate Onco result, chemo yes or no?

Posts.Content: Hi Volvox167 Prior to my DX in May I was running 3 to 4 times a week as well as attending a couple of bootcamp classes with the occasional spin class thrown in.  I had MX in May with immediate temporary expander implant, followed by 15 sessions of RT. I made sure I walked 3 to 5 miles a day after surgery and during RT even tough I found RT quite tiring but I wanted to maintain some level of fitness, I did feel as though I could have gone to spinning classes but I didn't want to aggravate my skin any more than was necessary during RT, i.e sweating and having to wear tight sports bra etc, it probably would have been fine as it turned out I didn't suffer skin problems with RT, thankfully!.  The breast care nurse advised me prior to surgery that it would be about 3months before I was back running and going to bootcamp, as soon as the 3 months was up I popped my trainers on and off I went (albeit it very slowly!) and am now back to running 3 to 4 times a week and have also been spinning a bit.  I haven't yet ventured back to a full on bootcamp class, not because I don't feel up to it but I am still getting used to having the implant ,  but have been doing a bit of  stuff at home, squats, sit ups, lunges etc and have also been attending a yoga class once a week.  Wishing you all the best :-)
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Thanks Dandelion54, I didn't know about that, I'll have a look into it. :-) x
Posts.Title: Coffee support groups

Posts.Content: Hi Frances I used R1 & R2 throughout my 15 sessions of RT and the R2 cream for two weeks afterwards.  None of the radiotherapy staff or BCN had heard of it so I bought them myself form the 'Waterjel' website and you're right it cost about £70.  I had no skin problems at all.  Lots of ladies have posted to say they've used Aloe Vera gel and E45 cream (both a lot cheaper!) and had no skin problems at all.  I opted to use the R1 & R2 as I had recon with temp implant in May and was just petrified of the skin breaking down! Best wishes
Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi all Does anyone know of any 'coffee groups' where us like minded people meet up and chat? I'm in the Banbury area of the UK.
Posts.Title: Coffee support groups

Posts.Content: Hi Dandelion54 Unfortunately no, I haven't managed to find a coffee group in Banbury ;-(
Posts.Title: Coffee support groups

Posts.Content: Hi Karen Thanks so much for the info. :-) x
Posts.Title: Coffee support groups

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry I had mastectomy and recon with expander implant in May followed by 3 weeks of radiotherapy which i finished 2 weeks ago, following oncotype test was not offered chemo.  I've been taking tamoxifen for 3 months, I have had some hot flushes but not too bad and I had started to experience them before, I'm 49, so they haven't come as a complete shock, other than that i've been ok, well with the exception of increased appetite which isn't too good lol.  I was given a leaflet from the Macmillan BCN with information about side effects which was a lot less frightening than the info that comes with the tablets and to be honest if I read the side effect of paracetamol I probably wouldn't want to take those either! My consultant said that most side effects settle down after a few months.  Why don't you give them a try and see how you feel after a couple of months as you can alway stop them if you find that you just can't tolerate them. Good luck :-)
Posts.Title: Side effects of tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Antsi I was diagnosed in March following my first routine mammogram, initially I was told I would need a lumpectomy followed by RT & tamoxifen, however, following an MRI ( which had been arranged due to me having very dense breasts) 3 further tumors were found and although small meant I would no longer be able to have a lumpectomy due to the size of the area involved in relation to the size of my breast, so had to have MX ( which I was 'happy' to have) I was then told I would need Chemo, RT & Tamoxifen, following surgery which included Sentinel node removel of which I had 'micro' cancer in one.  I'm ER + HER2 neg and a sample of tissue was sent off for the Oncotype DX test, the score came back low.  So, the final treatment plan for me was RT & Tamoxifen. I don't think a treatment plan can be finalised until they have all the results and it does vary from person to person as there is no 'one size fits all' All the best :-)
Posts.Title: Surgery in 10 days, then .... no idea

Posts.Content: I had mastectomy, no choice as had total of four tumors,  in May 2017 with immediate temporary expander implant, as I was having RT.  I opted for an implant as I wasn't a candidate for DIEP due to previous abdominal surgery.  I'm currently sporting 1 perky and 1 49 year old but have to say that despite it looking and feeling different I actually quite like my noob :-) I'm due to have the implant replaced for a permanent one later this year and my surgeon has offered to 'lift and reduce' the 49 year old sister at the same time to gain symmetry. :-)
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Hi Louise11 I had MX in May, I kept my pants on under hospital gown and took in a soft crop top style bra which the surgeon put on me whilst under aesthetic. They may let you keep your bra on until you get to the anaesthetist if that would make you feel more comfortable. Wishing you all the best fro tomorrow, you will be fine :-)
Posts.Title: Under wear when having surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Pussycatgirl I had mastectomy with immediate recon using a temporary expander implant in May, I was in hospital 3 days and had 2 drains which were removed about 48 hours after the op.  I elected to have the temp expander as I knew I was having radiotherapy following mastectomy and I had read that radiotherapy could affect the appearance of the implant (so far mine is ok) I think I have to wait around 6 months before I can exchange the temp implant with a permanent one. Wishing you all the very best :-)
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab I had mastectomy with temporary expander implant in May, I'm happy (?!) with how it looks but it has taken a bit of time to get used to how it feels, I'm back to running which I'm really pleased about and so far finding it ok.  I'm still getting used to feeling my pec muscle move for example when pushing myself up from the chair and opening the dishwasher it kind of twitches, bit of a weird sensation.  It does also feel as though its contracting and tightening sometimes although I'm not sure if thats the muscle or effects of radiotherapy. All the best
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrap Ah yes, could be different surgery, I think you're right in that they made a 'support' at the bottom for the implant to sit in. Don't get me wrong, I'm not breaking any records lol,  just plodding along but its good to get back to some excersise, have to shift some of 'chocolate peanut' weight I've put on since starting Tamoxifen!  :-) Hopefully you'll be able to get back to running soon. :-) xx
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi Pickles My Oncotype score was 16 so wasn't offered chemo and went straight to radiotherapy and Tamoxifen.  Still met with my Oncologist to go through all my results after pathology etc, she said that there was much debate amongst Oncologists that scores up to 24 were low enough not to warrant chemo due to the risks outweighing the benefits. At the end of the day you have to be comfortable with your decision, whichever way you decide to go. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx test unclear as what i should do next :(

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I've been taking Tamoxifen for just a couple of months.  You're right it's like having PMT when you want to eat constantly , I'm currently struggling to control my urge to eat chocolate peanuts all the time, I just have to limit what I keep in the cupboard..............hot flushes & night sweats not much fun but then I guess same/similar to going through the menopause.  Best wishes
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & urge to constantly eat

Posts.Content: I can only agree with what others have said. It is scary stuff but you will start to feel more in control once you know your treatment plan, as Ronstar has said stick to the official sites when looking stuff up. Try not too think too far ahead and just take one day at time. Wishing you all the best :-)
Posts.Title: Coping

Posts.Content: Thanks for posting this.  Have just finished watching it and can only echo what everyone else has said, I found it very positive. :-)
Posts.Title: BBC Scotland Beaston Cancer Centre - Episode One Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sainsbury's & Primark also sell very reasonably priced bras :-)
Posts.Title: Post surgery sports bras

Posts.Content: Hi Daydream47 I had the same op as you and also in May 2017.  Most of the time I'm not that aware of the implant but like you do get different sensations and pulling feeling on chest muscle for example when pulling, pushing or lifting.  I think because the implant is under the muscle it's more noticeable when the muscle is being used.
Posts.Title: Implant reconstruction and SNB advise please

Posts.Content: Hi Tallantire Yes I still have them about 15 sachets, I'm not sure how to message either, but feel free to add me as a friend. :-)
Posts.Title: My radiotherapy experience

Posts.Content: Hi Cbbbb Thank you for sharing.  I've started to have night sweats since starting Tamoxifen a couple of months ago.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and night sweats

Posts.Content: I was really worried that my skin would blister and break and compromise my implant, so relieved that it didn't and hopefully you'll be fine too particularly if you have not had any previous issues from Chemo & surgery. I moisturised 3-4 times a day, gets a bit tedious and its not always convenient to do so when going out/working etc but worth making the effort.  They will monitor your skin every day and if it stats to look sore then they should  give you something to help and you'll also have an appointment with the BCN to check how you're doing. Good luck, it'll be over before you know it. :-)
Posts.Title: My radiotherapy experience

Posts.Content: Hi all Just thought I'd share my August radiotherapy experience with you. Two weeks ago today I finished 15 sessions of Radiotherapy following MX and reconstruction with expander implant. I had radiotherapy at the Churchill in Oxford and found the staff very pleasant and they explained everything and answered any questions I had.  I was given a parking permit for the duration and my appointment times were round about the same time each day, I was seen on time, they were only running a little late twice. It was a 3-4 hour round trip for me, I elected to go weekends so that was a bit quieter and quicker.  I used R1 & R2 creams which I bought on line (none of the staff I mentioned it to had heard of it) and have not had any problems with my skin, have carried on using it for past 2 weeks once treatment had finished as I was told the radiotherapy would keep working for 10-14 days,  the skin has changed colour, a bit like when you  have a tan, my underarm was a little bit sore but I think that was where skin touches skin and hair regrowth from not shaving for a couple of weeks.  I continued to use normal shower gel and deodorant with no sensitivity.  I drank plenty of water to stay hydrated. I did feel tired now and then so had to take a couple of afternoon naps (I work from home so was able to work round them) It is a bit of a slog having to go 5 days a week and I was glad when it finished but the time did go quite quickly, especially as I work and have been doing lots to keep myself busy. I have about 8 of the R1 soothing gel sachets left that I would be happy to post out to someone who is or wants to use it, just PM me. Wishing all the best to everyone along this journey :-)
Posts.Title: My radiotherapy experience
